This thread similar to it's brother Yardstick Pure Builds, will be the focus of all Prestige Class builds. Although the rules for a "pure prestige build" are not as well defined, for simplicity sake's we will assume that every such build will be consist from ten (10) levels of a main class, followed by thirty (30) levels of  a single prestige class, so the class split for such an attempt will always be 10/30. All attempts that produce playable builds are welcome here, but if you have multiple versions of a single build, please bring forth the strongest one.

I will begin this thread with a Great Smiter build that also has the strongest possible Divine Wrath effect in the game.

posts.author: WhiZard
posts.content:
So if I wanted a wizard/shadowdancer it would be a minimum of 17 wizard levels just to qualify for the 10 hide prerequisite of shadowdancer. But 17 caster levels is level 9 spells, allowing for a power caster. I could similarly argue the same 17 levels for cleric or druid (allows for druids elemental shape, but thankfully not the dragon shape), each of these classes also having level 9 spells.

This has made me consider why must the traditional 10/30 split focus more on the 10 being a pure base class (and allowing it to grow higher if the prestige class prerequisites would require it), rather than focusing on the 10 being an exact number that can be split among multiple classes. For instance, wouldn't fighter 8/wizard 2/AA 30 be more focused on AA than wizard 12/AA 28 (which would have 6th level spells)?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: First of all, a Shadowdancer is an extremely poor choice for building a pure prestige class, even more for Wizards. Just because you could build a Wizard/SD that doesnt means you should, instead focus on the choices that give good results. You might want to check Ranger/Rogue for that combination though.

OK, Dwarves time and with quite a ferocious one at that, Kagain is a money-loving Dwarf that can take lot's of punishment and return it back where it came from. He has maximum Dwarven strength and Dev. Crit along with some potent combat tricks like improved knockdown, called shot and his migthy dwarven stance. Improved knockdown is there for obvious reasons but here comes the trick, whatever you cannot knockdown, you use your high AB to do repeated called shots - arm and turn it into an imbecile that cannot fight back. Finish them at your leisure. In modules/pw's that don't allow for Dev. posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: Ranger is great for this kind of stalker build. You have a full BAB class with stealth skills, so you can qualify after lvl 5 with +2 BAB compared to rogue, bard etc. You get ITWF in light armor for free and have 4 skillpts + int from the start. Ranger has improved outdoor stealth and spells to improve stealth and dex.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Weaponmaster next. Look at the AB you get from full WM!
I made a build with dev crit. The build will land crits in abundance. The fort saves are a weak spot with WM. I have tried to improve the fort saves with feats to be able to handle a dev crit environment better.
Scimitar has the highest critical threat range available, and with a one-hander you can improve the AC with a shield, a good idea since you have to cross class tumble.
As for the 10/30 split; F12/WM28 would have been a stronger build with an extra feat and EWS available. F11/R1/WM28 would enable EWS and full tumble.

This thread similar to it's brother Yardstick Pure Builds, will be the focus of all Prestige Class builds. Although the rules for a "pure prestige build" are not as well defined, for simplicity sake's we will assume that every such build will be consist from ten (10) levels of a main class, followed by thirty (30) levels of  a single prestige class, so the class split for such an attempt will always be 10/30.
